1: अक्ष (1) = विभीतक (Avk; Bpn, p. 9; Dgv, nr. 149; Dn 1, 212; Gul; HB; HK; KB 2, p. 1017-1020; MW; Pr 220; PW; Rn 11, 322-323; V 6, p. 160; Vśs); (2) a) = रुद्राक्ष (Avk; Vśs); b) the seed of रुद्राक्ष (MW; PW); (3) a) = इन्द्राक्ष (Vśs: = the tuberous root of the creeper called ऋषभक); b) = ऋषभक (Avk; Vśs); ऋषभक is an unidentifiable plant, but Vśs identifies it as CARPOPOGON PRURIENS; see: कपि-कच्छू̆; (4) = देवशिरीष (Vśs, unidentified).
2: अगरु (sometimes considered to be a synonym of अगुरु) (1) a) Chopra: [COMMIPHORA ROXBURGHII (ARN.) ENGL.] = [C. AGALLOCHA (WIGHT ET ARN.) ENGL.] = BALSAMODENDRUM ROXBURGHII ARN. = AMYRIS COMMIPHORA ROXB.; b) KB 1, p. 528-529: COMMIPHORA AGALLOCHA ENGL. = BALSA-MODENDRUM ROXBURGHIII ARN. = AMYRIS COMMIPHORA ROXB.; the Index Kewensis disagrees with Chopra and KB and distinguishes: a) COMMIPHORA MUKUL ENGL. = C. ROXBURGHII ENGL. = BAL-SAMODENDRUM ROXBURGHII STOCKS = B. WIGHTII ARN.; b) COMMIPHORA ROXBURGHII ALSTON = C. AGALLOCHA ENGL. = BALSAMODENDRUM AGALLOCHA WIGHT ET ARN. = B. COMMI-PHORA ROYLE = B. ROXBURGHII ARN. = AMYRIS COMMI-PHORA ROXB.; the confusion in the nomenclature is due to the fact that Chopra identifies C. ROXBURGHII ENGL. with C. AGALLOCHA ENGL., distinguished as two species in the Index Kewensis, and that he considers C. MUKUL ENGL. as a separate species, synonymous with B. MUKUL HOOK. EX STOCKS, while C. MUKUL ENGL. is a synonym of C. ROXBURGHII ENGL. in the Index Kewensis; Hooker describes (1, p. 529): a) BALSAMO-DENDRON MUKUL HOOK. EX STOCKS = B. ROXBURGHII STOCKS = (?) B. WIGHTII ARN., and b) B. ROXBURGHII ARN. = AMY-RIS COMMIPHORA ROXB. = (?) AMYRIS AGALLOCHA ROXB.; Cooke describes (1, p. 212-213) COMMIPHORA MUKUL ENGL. = BALSAMODENDRON MUKUL HOOK. EX STOCKS = B. ROX-BURGHII STOCKS (NON ARNOTT); Duthie (1, p. 139-140) agrees with Cooke; (2) AQUILARIA AGALLOCHA ROXB. (Chopra; IRM 1, p. 89-90; KB 3, p. 2171-2172; Nadk. 1, nr. 208; Watt CP, p. 72-74); (3) AMYRIS AGALLOCHA ROXB. (MW; PW); acc. to HK this is a synonym of AQUILARIA AGALLOCHA ROXB., but the Index Kewensis regards it as a separate species; (4) SAPIUM SEBIFERUM ROXB. (KB 3, p. 2284); (5) EXCOECARIA AGALLOCHA LINN. (Chopra; KB 3, p. 2285-2286); (6) DYSOXYLUM MALABARICUM BEDD. EX C. DC. (Avk; Nadk. 1, nr. 902).

32: एलवालु (क) Much confusion exists concerning this substance as will become apparent from the material collected: (1) Bpn, कर्पूरादिवर्ग 120: it is also called कपित्थत्वच् (the bark of कपित्थ). Acc. to the Hindī comm. (p. 262-263) the substance is described somewhere in Bhā. pra. as resembling कङ्कोल and smelling like कुष्ठ। In the same comm. three different identifications are made mention of: a) PRUNUS CERASUS LINN., b) GISEKIA PHARNACIOIDES LINN., c) MUKIA SCABRELLA ARN. (Index Kewensis: MELOTHRIA MADERASPATANA COGN. = MUKIA SCABRELLA ARN. = MUKIA MADERA-SPATANA M. ROEM). (2) DWH 2, p. 105-107: GISEKIA PHARNACIOIDES LINN.; p. 105: “This plant is called in Sanskrit वालुक and एलवालुक on account of the number of large raphides contained in the leaves, and which give them the appearance of being full of sand (वालु).” (Raphides are minute intracellular crystals, usually of an acicular form). (3) Gul: cherry tree (PRUNUS CERASUS LINN.). (4) HB, p. 21: GISEKIA PHARNACIOIDES LINN.; ibid., footnote 70: “एलवालु is mentioned Su. Sū. 38, 14, where Ḍa.'s comm. explains it as a reddish powder (हरिवालुक), resembling that of the seeds of the कृष्णगन्धा (कृष्णगन्धिकफल)। The latter is a name of the horse-radish tree or शिग्रु or शोभाञ्जन;” ibid., p. 91, footnote 74: “In the Phar. Ind. (= DWH) 2, p. 105, it is wrongly identified with वालुक; the seeds, supplied to me by a native druggist, seem to be simply those of chickweed.” (5) HK: quotes the identifications of PW and Hoernle. (6) Kav, p. 37: a kind of red powder made of some seeds obtainable of every native druggist, not identified; p. 294: a fragrant powder of a bark sold under that name; it is believed to come from the Spice Islands; p. 642: Gaṅgādhara takes it as implying तेजवल, a kind of wood apparently dry but juicy within; it is brought from Nepal. (7) KB 2, p. 1187-1188: GISEKIA PHARNACIOIDES LINN. (8) MW: the fragrant bark of FERONIA ELEPHANTUM (कपित्थत्वच्); a granular substance (apparently a vegetable of a reddish-brown colour, used as a drug and perfume). (9) PW: the fragrant bark of FERONIA ELEPHANTUM (कपित्थत्वच्), used medicinally. (10) V 7, p. 67: GISEKIA PHARNACIOIDES. (11) Vśs: name of a perfume; a red powder sold under that name; the seed of some plant. (12) Ḍa. on Su. Sū. 38, 14 (printed ed., different from Hoernle's text): “a reddish powder (हरिवालुक), resembling the black, fragrant कट्फ-ल;” कट्फल is usually identified as MYRICA NAGI THUNB.
33: एला Two kinds of एला are distinguished: 1) सूक्ष्मैला or क्षुद्रैला, the small cardamom, and 2) स्थूलैला or बृहदेला, the large cardamom. (1) ELETTARIA CARDAMOMUM MATON (Avk; Bpn, p. 222-223; Cho-pra; Dgv, nr. 308; Dutt; DWH 3, p. 428-436; Gul; HB; HK; IRM 3, p. 149-160; KB 4, p. 2442-2444; Nadk. 1, nr. 924; V 1, p. 147; Vśs; Watt CP, p. 511-517) = E. MAJOR SM. (Avk) = E. REPENS BAILL. (Avk; Nadk. 1, nr. 924) = ALPINIA CARDAMOMUM ROXB. (KB 4, p. 2442-2444); (2) AMOMUM SUBULATUM ROXB. (Bpn, p. 221; Chopra; Dgv, nr. 308; Dutt; DWH 3, p. 436; HK; KB 4, p. 2432-2433; Nadk. 1, nr. 154; V 1, p. 148; Vśs; Watt CP, p. 65); (3) A. AMARUM F. P. SMITH (Nadk. 1, nr. 150); (4) A. XANTHIOIDES WALL. (Dy, p. 788-789); (5) A. KEPULAGA SPRAGUE ET BURKILL (Bpn, p. 224: used as a substitute) = A. CARDAMOMUM ROXB. (NON LINN.) (Roxb., p. 24: एला); (6) A. AROMATICUM ROXB. (Bpn, p. 222: used as a substitute).
34: एलावालुक This term occurs Kauṭ. 2, 25, 27 (text p. 79; transl. Kangle p. 178; transl. J. J. Meyer p. 187; transl. Sham. p. 133). Sham. renders it by SOLANUM MELONGENA, without any comment. J. J. Meyer takes it as the fragrant bark of FERONIA ELEPHANTUM (एलवालुक), but remarks that the reading एलावालुक makes it probable that one should translate: एला and वालुक (i. e. हरिवालुक, the fragrant bark of कपित्थ); Kangle translates: cardamum, वालुक। Acc. to Vśs एलावालुक is a synonym of एलवालुक।

(Nadk. 1, nr. 796); there is no agreement about the nomenclature of the species of Datura: Hooker considers D. METEL LINN. and D. FASTUOSA LINN. as separate species (vol. 4, p. 242-243), as well as Cooke (vol. 2, p. 343-344), but a different classification is found in Chopra: a) D. INNOXIA MILL. is a separate species, b) D. (Chopra); Watt (CP, p. 492-493) observes: “Roxburgh (see Flora Indica, p. 726-728) assigned four or five types of tubers to separate specific posi-tions, chiefly on account of their shape and colour. He, however, ad-mitted that he would be quite prepared to accept all these races as belonging to the same species.” Hooker (Flora of India 6, p. 296-297) described D. ALATA LINN. as a species and considered b, c, d and e as “imperfectly known and indeterminable species;” Prain and Burkill (see Watt, l. c.) have recorded Roxburgh's four forms (b, c, d and e) under D. ALATA LINN. and have formed varietal positions for each; the Index Kewensis gives the five forms, mentioned as a-e, as separate species; see also the article: Dioscorea, IRM 3, p. 67-76; f) [D. ALATA LINN. VAR. GLOBOSA PRAIN] (KB 4, p. 2490); (2) IPOMOEA BATATAS POIR. (KB 3, p. 1719-1720; V 9, p. 50) = CONVOLVULUS BATATAS LINN. (Avk) = BATATAS EDULIS CHOISY (Bpn, p. 679-680; MW; PW); (3) RANDIA ULIGINOSA DC. (DWH 2, p. 207; KB 2, p. 1272-1273; V 6, p. 89) = GARDENIA ULIGINOSA RETZ. (KB 2, p. 1272-1273) = POSOQUERIA ULIGINOSA (WILLD.) ROXB. (KB 2, p. 1272-1273); (4) TINOSPORA CORDIFOLIA MIERS = COCCULUS CORDIFOLIUS DC. 238: विदलामलक This term occurs Kauṭ. 2, 15, 18 (text p. 74; transl. Kangle p. 142; transl. J. J. Meyer p. 141; transl. Sham. p. 101); (see App. 3: अम्ल). Sham. is of the opinion that it is a synonym of आमलक; J. J. Meyer (p. 141, footnote 7) is unsure about the meaning of the word; he seems to prefer to take the word as a compound and remarks that विदल (acc. to the dictionaries) designates BAUHINIA VARIEGATA, but acc. to Gaṇ. the pomegranate (दाडिम). In my opinion the word विदलामलक is a compound and the first member is विदल or विदला। विदल: (1) BAUHINIA VARIEGATA LINN. (MW; Vśs: = रक्तकाञ्चन); (2) B. PURPUREA LINN. (Vśs: = रक्तकाञ्चन); (3) the seeds of PUNICA GRANATUM LINN. (Vśs). विदला: (1) IPOMOEA TURPETHUM R. BR. (MW; Vśs); (2) = सातला (Vśs; variously identified, but acc. to Vśs. EUPHORBIA NERIFOLIA LINN.); (3) the bark of PUNICA GRANATUM LINN. (MW). The best solution is to read विदल and to take it in the sense of दाडिम (PUNICA GRANATUM LINN.) because the pomegranate is usually enumerated as one of the fruits called फलाम्ल। (Kangle also trans-lates: pomegranate).

240: विलङ्ग This plant is mentioned Kauṭ. 2, 25, 29 (text p. 79; transl. Kangle p. 178; transl. J. J. Meyer p. 186; transl. Sham. p. 132); see App. 3: आसव। Sham. does not translate the term. J. J. Meyer remarks (p. 188, note 1) that it may denote a climbing plant, that it is a synonym of विडङ्ग (EMBELIA RIBES) acc. to Stein and that it is a synonym of अमोघा acc. to Gaṇ. अमोघा: 1) STEREOSPERMUM SUAVEOLENS DC. (Vśs) = BIGNONIA SUAVEOLENS ROXB. (MW; Vśs); 2) TERMINALIA CHEBULA RETZ. (DWH 2, p. 1; Vśs: = हरीतकी); 3) T. CITRINA ROXB. EX FLEM. (MW, = हरीतकी); 4) ERYCIBE PANICULATA ROXB. (MW); 5) = पद्मभेद (Vśs, unidentified); 6) EMBELIA RIBES BURM.F. (Bpn, p. 52, = विडङ्ग); 7) PHYLLANTHUS EMBLICA LINN. (Cakra on Ca.Sū. 4, 18: = आमलकी).

259: गुग्गुलु usually designates the gum of COMMIPHORA MUKUL ENGL.; (12) CINNAMOMUM TAMALA T. NEES ET EBERM. (KB 3, p. 2146-2147); (13) [C. ZEYLANICUM BREYN] (see त्वच्) (KB 3, p. 2149-2150); (14) Cassia-bark (MW; PW); (15) myrrh (MW; PW).
260: सौवीर(क) See कर्कन्धू̆, कोल, बदर। (1) ZIZYPHUS SATIVA GAERTN. (Dgv, nr. 84, = राजकोल = राज-बदर; V 1, p. 163) = Z. VULGARIS LAM. (Dgv, nr. 84; V 1, p. 163); (2) a) = कोल (HK); b) = बृहद्बदर (Vśs); J. J. Meyer, transl. Kauṭ., p. 141, note 8: Gaṇ. explains that कोल is the small, बदर the large and सौवीरक the sweet jujube. Ḍa. on Su.Sū. 46, 139: बदर is large, कोल is of a moderate size and कर्कन्धु is small; सौवीर is the largest (among the jujube-fruits) and is, both ripe and unripe, sweet.
261: स्पृक्का (1) TRIGONELLA CORNICULATA LINN. (Dutt; HB; HK; MW; PW); (2) MELILOTUS OFFICINALIS LAM. (Gul) = TRIFOLIUM OFFICINALE LINN. (Bpn, p. 265: acc. to some); (3) ANISOMELES MALABARICA R. BR. 262: हपुषा (1) a) black stalks like those of black pepper, possessed of an aroma-tic smell (Dutt; HK; Kav); b) name of a partic. substance, said to be of a long form and black colour, and smelling like raw meat or fish; it is of two kinds (MW); c) a partic. plant of two kinds, smelling like fish; the fruits of one kind resemble those of the अश्वत्थ (PW); d) हपुषा: an article of trade that is of a black colour and of a long form like the stalks of black pepper (मरीच) (Vśs); हवुषा: a fruit of that name; it is of two kinds; one is like a fish and of a musty smell; the other resembles अश्वत्थ fruits and smells like fish; their qualities are the same (Vśs); (2) JUNIPERUS COMMUNIS LINN. (Bpn, p. 50-51; Chopra; Dgv, nr. 302; Gul; KB 3, p. 2380-2382; Nadk. 1, nr. 1383); (3) TAMARIX GALLICA LINN. (Bpn, p. 51: acc. to some); (4) FLUGGEA LEUCOPYRUS WILLD. 318: golla Sbm. 4, 137 mentions a golajakaṣāya, comm. aśvatthaphalaṃ loke ‘gola’ nāmnā vyavahriyate. golaka = takkola acc. to comm. on Haram. 5, 129. takkola is difficult to identify; acc. to S.N. Yoganarasimhan and V.S. Togunashi in SCA 31, 8, Feb. 1979, p. 764 it is Vitex altissima Linn. f. Bheṣajakalpa 64 mentions takkola (not identified in the notes). tak-kola = kakkola acc. to Vśs; kakkola is sometimes identified as Piper cubeba Linn. f. (Sharma; Bt.).

342: tṛṇadruma, tṛṇavṛkṣa The following are called tṛṇadrumāḥ or tṛṇavṛkṣāh: tāla and all si-milar trees, kramuka, ketakī, kharjūrī and nālikera and the like (Rā. nigh., pariśiṣṭa 3, 39); tāla, nālikera, ghoṇṭā (= kramuka, l. c.), hin-tāla, kharjūra, ketakī, tālī and kharjūrī (Amarakośa 2, 4, 169-170); hintāla, lāṅgalī, kramuka, tala (= tāla, comm. ad l. c.), kharjūrī, tālikā (= tālī = tamālikā acc. to Rā.nigh., pariśiṣṭa 3, 37; = hrasvā tālajātiḥ acc. to comm. ad Śivakoṣa 338), kharjūra and krakacacchada (= ketakī, comm. ad l. c.) (Śivakoṣa 338); kharjūra, tāla, kharjūrī, tālī, hintāla, ketaka, kramuka and nālikera (Nś. 183).
